Step 1: Understand the key information provided in the passage.
- Recordings of angry bees can scare off big, tough African elephants.
- Beehives (real or recorded) may prevent elephants from damaging farmers' crops.
- Scientist Lucy King wanted to find out if African honeybees could discourage elephants from eating crops.
- Lucy found a wild beehive, recorded the sound of angry bees, and played it to groups of elephants.
- Half the elephant groups left the area within ten seconds after hearing the angry bees' sound.
- When Lucy played the sound of a waterfall instead, the elephants were undisturbed.

prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
Recordings of angry bees are enough to send big, tough African elephants running away, a new study says. Beehives (蜂窝)-either recorded or real-may even prevent elephants from damaging farmer's crops.In 2002, scientist Lucy King and her team found that elephants avoid certain trees with bees living in them. Today,  Lucy wants to see if African honeybees might discourage elephants from eating crops. But before she asked farmer to go to the trouble of setting up beehives on their farms, she needed to find out if the bees would scare elephants away.Lucy found a wild beehive inside a tree in northern Kenya and set up a recorder. Then she threw a stone into the beehive, which burst into life. Lucy and her assistant hid in their car until the angry bees had calmed down. Next，Lucy searched out elephant families in Samburu National Reserve in northern Kenya and put a speaker in a close to each family.From a distance, Lucy switched on the pre-recorded sound of angry bees while at the same time recording the elephants with a video camera. Half the elephant groups left the area within ten seconds. Out of a total of 17 groups, only one group ignored the sound of the angry bees. Lucy reported that all the young elephants immediately ran to their mothers to hide under them. When Lucy Played the sound of a waterfall (瀑布) instead of the angry bees to many of the same elephant families, the animals were undisturbed. Even after four minutes, most of the groups stayed in one place.Lucy is now studying whether the elephants will continue to avoid the sound of angry bees after hearing it several times. She hasn't tested enough groups yet to know, but her initial (最初的) results were promising enough to begin trials with farmers. She has now begun placing speakers in the fields to see if elephants are frightened away.
We know from the passage that elephants may he frightened of         .
(A)loud noises   
(B)some crops
(C)video cameras 
(D)angry bees

3. Before asking farmers to set up beehives on their farms, Lucy needed to find out if the bees would scare elephants away.

Beehives (蜂窝)-either recorded or real-may even prevent elephants from damaging farmer's crops.In 2002, scientist Lucy King and her team found that elephants avoid certain trees with bees living in them. Today,  Lucy wants to see if African honeybees might discourage elephants from eating crops. But before she asked farmer to go to the trouble of setting up beehives on their farms, she needed to find out if the bees would scare elephants away.Lucy found a wild beehive inside a tree in northern Kenya and set up a recorder. Then she threw a stone into the beehive, which burst into life. Lucy and her assistant hid in their car until the angry bees had calmed down. Next，Lucy searched out elephant families in Samburu National Reserve in northern Kenya and put a speaker in a close to each family.From a distance, Lucy switched on the pre-recorded sound of angry bees while at the same time recording the elephants with a video camera. Half the elephant groups left the area within ten seconds. Out of a total of 17 groups, only one group ignored the sound of the angry bees. Lucy reported that all the young elephants immediately ran to their mothers to hide under them. When Lucy Played the sound of a waterfall (瀑布) instead of the angry bees to many of the same elephant families, the animals were undisturbed. Even after four minutes, most of the groups stayed in one place.Lucy is now studying whether the elephants will continue to avoid the sound of angry bees after hearing it several times. She hasn't tested enough groups yet to know, but her initial (最初的) results were promising enough to begin trials with farmers. She has now begun placing speakers in the fields to see if elephants are frightened away.
Which of the following is true according to the passage?
(A)Young elephants ignore African honeybees.
(B)Waterfalls can make elephants stay in one place.
(C)Elephants do not go near trees with bees living in them. 
(D)Farmers do not allow Lucy to conduct tests in their fields.

To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step:

prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
You are the collector in the gallery of your life. You collect. You might not mean to but you do. One out of three people collects tangible（有形的）things such as cats, photos and noisy toys.There are among some 40 collections that are being shown at “The Museum Of”—the first of several new museums which, over the next two years, will exhibit the objects accumulated by unknown collectors. In doing so, they will promote a popular culture of museums, not what museums normally represent.Some of the collections are fairly common—records, model houses. Others are strangely beautiful—branches that have fallen from tree, for example. But they all reveal （显露）a lot of things: ask someone what they collect and their answers will tell you who they are.Other on the way include “The museum of Collectors” and “The Museum of Me.”These new ones, it is hoped, will build on the success of “The Museum Of.” The thinkers behind the project want to explore why people collect, and what it means to do so. They hope that visitors who may not have considered themselves collectors will begin to see they, too, collect.Some collectors say they started or stopped making collections at important point: the beginning or end of adolescence—“it’s a growing-up thing; you stop when you grow up,”says one. Other painful times are mentioned, such as the end of a relationship. For time and life can seem so uncontrollable that a steady serial（顺序排列的）arrangement is comforting.
How will the new museums promote a popular culture of museums?
(A)By collecting more tangible things.
(B)By showing what ordinary people have collected.
(C)By correcting what museums normally represent.
(D)By accumulating 40 collections two years from now.

To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step:

1. The passage introduces Ashoka, an association founded by Bill Drayton that has been fighting poverty, promoting education, and encouraging small businesses for the past 27 years.

2. The passage then discusses Ashoka's goal of supporting "changemakers" - people who are seeking to solve urgent problems and create a world where every citizen is a changemaker.

3. The passage explains Drayton's belief that anyone can become an agent for change, and that it's important to simply give yourself permission to solve problems that you care about.

4. The passage then provides an example of an Ashoka project started in 1995 in Dhaka, Bangladesh, which addressed the city's rubbish problem. The project educated poor people to compost the natural waste, and then sold the compost to local farmers who were struggling with expensive chemical fertilizers.

5. The passage concludes by stating that Drayton is optimistic that Ashoka will make serious, practical progress in bringing about social change by changing the way we look at economic development.

Based on the content of the passage, the best title would be:

(A) Changemakers

This title captures the core focus of the passage, which is about Ashoka's efforts to support and empower "changemakers" who are seeking to solve urgent problems and create positive social change.
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
You may not  have heard of Ashoka,  but for the past 27 years,this association, founded by Bill Drayton, has fought  poverty (贫穷)and sickness, promoted education and  encouraged small businesses. So they educated the poor people in the city to compost (把……制成堆粪)this waste . At first , they were refused ,but once they were able to persuade them that there was money to be made , the project took off. In 2009 sales were $14,000.Drayton is optimistic that in ten years Ashoka will be making really serious ,practical progress in bringing about social change by changing the way we look at economic development.

To solve this problem, we need to carefully read the passage and identify the relevant information about Susanna Reid.

Let's go through the passage step-by-step:

1. The passage introduces Susanna Reid as the presenter of "Good Morning Britain" who is known for "grilling guests on the sofa every morning".

2. It then mentions that Susanna Reid is now "cooking up a storm in her latest role" where she is "showing families how to prepare delicious and nutritious meals on a tight budget".

3. The passage states that Susanna Reid has been able to "put a lot of what she's learnt into practice in her own home, preparing meals for sons, Sam, 14, Finn, 13, and Jack, 11."

From this information, we can conclude that:

(B) She has started a new programme called "Save Money: Good Food" where she helps families prepare affordable and healthy meals.

The passage does not provide any information to support the other options:
(A) There is no mention of Susanna Reid embarrassing her guests.
(C) The passage states that she is known for "grilling guests on the sofa every morning", which suggests that she does not dislike working early.
(D) The passage indicates that Susanna Reid has been able to apply the lessons from her new programme to her own home and family, implying that she has had to work with a tight budget.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) She has started a new programme.
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
*Good Morning Britain*’s Susanna Reid is used to grilling guests on the sofa every morning, but she is cooking up a storm in her latest role – showing families how to prepare delicious and nutritious meals on a tight budget.In *Save Money: Good Food*, she visits a different home each week and with the help of chef Matt Tebbutt offers top tips on how to reduce food waste, while preparing recipes for under £5 per family a day. And the *Good Morning Britain* presenter says she’s been able to put a lot of what she’s learnt into practice in her own home, preparing meals for sons, Sam, 14, Finn, 13, and Jack, 11.“We love Mexican churros, so I buy them on my phone from my local Mexican takeaway restaurant,” she explains. “I pay £5 for a portion (一份), but Matt makes them for 26p a portion, because they are flour, water, sugar and oil. Everybody can buy takeaway food, but sometimes we’re not aware how cheaply we can make this food ourselves.”The eight-part series (系列节目), *Save Money: Good Food*, follows in the footsteps of ITV’s *Save Money: Good Health*, which gave viewers advice on how to get value from the vast range of health products on the market.With food our biggest weekly household expense, Susanna and Matt spend time with a different family each week. In tonight’s Easter special they come to the aid of a family in need of some delicious inspiration on a budget. The team transforms the family’s long weekend of celebration with less expensive but still tasty recipes.
What do we know about Susanna Reid?
(A)She enjoys embarrassing her guests.
(B)She has started a new programme.
(C)She dislikes working early in the morning.
(D)She has had a tight budget for her family.
question:

And the *Good Morning Britain* presenter says she’s been able to put a lot of what she’s learnt into practice in her own home, preparing meals for sons, Sam, 14, Finn, 13, and Jack, 11.“We love Mexican churros, so I buy them on my phone from my local Mexican takeaway restaurant,” she explains. “I pay £5 for a portion (一份), but Matt makes them for 26p a portion, because they are flour, water, sugar and oil. Everybody can buy takeaway food, but sometimes we’re not aware how cheaply we can make this food ourselves.”The eight-part series (系列节目), *Save Money: Good Food*, follows in the footsteps of ITV’s *Save Money: Good Health*, which gave viewers advice on how to get value from the vast range of health products on the market.With food our biggest weekly household expense, Susanna and Matt spend time with a different family each week. In tonight’s Easter special they come to the aid of a family in need of some delicious inspiration on a budget. output:
To solve this problem, we need to understand the role of Matt Tebbutt in the show "Save Money: Good Food" that Susanna Reid is hosting.

Step 1: Identify the key information from the passage.
- Susanna Reid is hosting a show called "Save Money: Good Food" where she visits different homes and prepares meals with the help of chef Matt Tebbutt.
- The show aims to teach families how to prepare delicious and nutritious meals on a tight budget, and how to reduce food waste.
- Matt Tebbutt helps Susanna by offering top tips and preparing recipes for under £5 per family a day.

Step 2: Analyze the options and choose the correct answer.
(A) He buys cooking materials for her: This is not mentioned in the passage.
(B) He prepares food for her kids: The passage states that Susanna prepares meals for her own sons, not that Matt prepares food for them.
(C) He assists her in cooking matters: This is the correct answer. The passage clearly states that "with the help of chef Matt Tebbutt, she offers top tips on how to reduce food waste, while preparing recipes for under £5 per family a day."
(D) He invites guest families for her: The passage mentions that Susanna visits "a different home each week," but it does not indicate that Matt Tebbutt is responsible for inviting the guest families.

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) He assists her in cooking matters.

question:
*Good Morning Britain*’s Susanna Reid is used to grilling guests on the sofa every morning, but she is cooking up a storm in her latest role – showing families how to prepare delicious and nutritious meals on a tight budget.In *Save Money: Good Food*, she visits a different home each week and with the help of chef Matt Tebbutt offers top tips on how to reduce food waste, while preparing recipes for under £5 per family a day. And the *Good Morning Britain* presenter says she’s been able to put a lot of what she’s learnt into practice in her own home, preparing meals for sons, Sam, 14, Finn, 13, and Jack, 11.“We love Mexican churros, so I buy them on my phone from my local Mexican takeaway restaurant,” she explains. “I pay £5 for a portion (一份), but Matt makes them for 26p a portion, because they are flour, water, sugar and oil. Everybody can buy takeaway food, but sometimes we’re not aware how cheaply we can make this food ourselves.”The eight-part series (系列节目), *Save Money: Good Food*, follows in the footsteps of ITV’s *Save Money: Good Health*, which gave viewers advice on how to get value from the vast range of health products on the market.With food our biggest weekly household expense, Susanna and Matt spend time with a different family each week. In tonight’s Easter special they come to the aid of a family in need of some delicious inspiration on a budget. The team transforms the family’s long weekend of celebration with less expensive but still tasty recipes.
How does Matt Tebbutt help Susanna?
(A)He buys cooking materials for her.
(B)He prepares food for her kids.
(C)He assists her in cooking matters.
(D)He invites guest families for her.

output:
To solve this problem, I will read through the passage step-by-step and analyze the content of the fourth paragraph.

The first three paragraphs introduce the TV show "Save Money: Good Food" and Susanna Reid's role in it. They explain how the show helps families prepare nutritious meals on a budget, and provide an example of how Susanna has put what she's learned into practice in her own home.

In the fourth paragraph, the author states:
"The eight-part series (系列节目), *Save Money: Good Food*, follows in the footsteps of ITV's *Save Money: Good Health*, which gave viewers advice on how to get value from the vast range of health products on the market."

This indicates that the author is providing some background information on the "Save Money" series, by mentioning the previous show "Save Money: Good Health" and how it gave viewers advice on health products.

So the correct answer is (C) Add some background information.

The author is not summarizing the previous paragraphs, providing advice to readers, or introducing a new topic - they are simply providing some additional context about the "Save Money" series that the current show is a part of.

To solve this problem, we need to analyze the information provided in the passage and make inferences about languages in hunter-gatherer times.

Step 1: Understand the key information about languages in the passage.
- In hunter-gatherer times, small, tightly knit groups developed their own patterns of speech independent of each other.
- Experts believe that 10,000 years ago, when the world had just 5-10 million people, they spoke perhaps 12,000 languages.
- As people started settling down to become farmers, their languages became more settled and fewer in number.

Step 2: Identify the possible inferences about languages in hunter-gatherer times.
(A) They developed very fast: This is not supported by the passage, which indicates that the languages developed independently in small, tightly knit groups.
(B) They were large in number: This is supported by the passage, which states that there were perhaps 12,000 languages when the world had only 5-10 million people.
(C) They had similar patterns: This is not supported by the passage, which states that the groups developed their own patterns of speech independent of each other.
(D) They were closely connected: This is supported by the passage, which describes the groups as "small, tightly knit."

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) and (D).
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
Languages have been coming and going for thousands of years, but in recent times there has been less coming and a lot more going. When the world was still populated by hunter-gatherers, small, tightly knit (联系) groups developed their own patterns of speech independent of each other. Some language experts believe that 10,000 years ago, when the world had just five to ten million people, they spoke perhaps 12,000 languages between them.Soon afterwards, many of those people started settling down to become farmers, and their languages too became more settled and fewer in number. In recent centuries, trade, industrialisation, the development of the nation-state and the spread of universal compulsory education, especially globalisation and better communications in the past few decades, all have caused__ __many languages to disappear, and dominant languages such as English, Spanish and Chinese are increasingly taking over.At present, the world has about 6,800 languages. The distribution of these languages is hugely uneven. The general rule is that mild zones have relatively few languages, often spoken by many people, while hot, wet zones have lots, often spoken by small numbers. Europe has only around 200 languages; the Americas about 1,000; Africa 2,400; and Asia and the Pacific perhaps 3,200, of which Papua New Guinea alone accounts for well over 800. The median number (中位数) of speakers is a mere 6,000, which means that half the world’s languages are spoken by fewer people than that.Already well over 400 of the total of 6,800 languages are close to extinction (消亡), with only a few elderly speakers left. Pick, at random, Busuu in Cameroon (eight remaining speakers), Chiapaneco in Mexico (150), Lipan Apache in the United States (two or three) or Wadjigu in Australia (one, with a question-mark): none of these seems to have much chance of survival.
What can we infer about languages in hunter-gatherer times?
(A)They developed very fast.
(B)They were large in number.
(C)They had similar patterns.
(D)They were closely connected.

1. The text states that we keep using our old devices even after they go out of style, which is bad for the environment and our wallets, as these outdated devices consume much more energy than the newer ones that do the same things.

2. The researchers tracked the environmental costs for each product throughout its life cycle, from mining the minerals to when we stop using the device. This method provided a readout for how home energy use has evolved since the early 1990s.

3. The text groups devices by generation: desktop computers, basic mobile phones, and box-set TVs in 1992; digital cameras in 1997; and MP3 players, smart phones, and LCD TVs in 2002, followed by tablets and e-readers in 2007.

4. The average number of electronic devices per household rose from 4 in 1992 to 13 in 2007. We're not just keeping these old devices, we continue to use them.

5. The analysis showed that old desktop monitors and box TVs with cathode ray tubes are the worst devices, with their energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions more than doubling from 1992 to 2007.

6. The researchers found that more on-demand entertainment viewing on tablets instead of TVs and desktop computers could cut energy consumption by 44%.

Based on this, the answer to the question "What does the author think of new devices?" is (C) They cost more to use at home.

(D)They go out of style quickly.

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the steps provided in the text:

1. Recite and repeat in conversation: When you hear a person's name, repeat it and say it to yourself several times.
2. Ask the other person to recite and repeat: You can ask the person to spell their name and pronounce it correctly for you.
3. Admit you don't know: Admitting that you can't remember someone's name can actually make people relaxed, and they will feel sympathy if you say you're working to remember names better.
4. Use associations: Link each person you meet with one thing you find interesting or unusual about them, and write down the associations.
5. Limit the number of new names you learn at one time: When meeting a group of people, concentrate on remembering just two or three names, and focus on first names first.
6. Go early: Consider going early to events, when there are fewer people, to make it easier to remember names.

Based on the information provided in the text, the answer to the question "How will most people feel when you try hard to remember their names?" is (C) They will be delighted.

The text states that "Most people will be pleased by the effort you're making to learn their names." This indicates that people will generally be delighted when you make an effort to remember their names.
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
Remembering names is an important social skill．Here are some ways to master it．__Recite and repeat in conversation．__    When you hear a person’s name，repeat it．Immediately say it to yourself several times without moving your lips．You could also repeat the name in a way that does not sound forced or artificial．   __ Ask the other person to recite and repeat．__    You can let other people help you remember their names．After you’ve been introduced to someone，ask that person to spell the name and pronounce it correctly for you．Most people will be pleased by the effort you’re making to learn their names．    __Admit you don’t know．__    Admitting that you can’t remember someone’s name can actually make people relaxed．Most of them will feel sympathy if you say．“I’m working to remember names better．Yours is right on the tip of my tongue．What is it again?”    __Use associations．__    Link each person yon meet with one thing you find interesting or unusual．For example，you could make a mental note: "Vicki Cheng -- tall, black hair.” To reinforce (加强) your associations, write them on a small card as soon as possible.     __Limit the number of new names you learn at one time.__     When meeting a group of people, concentrate on remembering just two or three names. Free yourself from remembering every one. Few of the people in mass introductions expect you to remember their names. Another way is to limit yourself to learning just first names. Last names can come later.    __ Go early.__     Consider going early to conferences, parties and classes. Sometimes just a few people show up on time. That's fewer names for you to remember. And as more people arrive, you can hear them being introduced to others -- an automatic review for you.
How will most people feel when you try hard to remember their names?
 A. They will be moved.                   
(B)They will be annoyed.
(C)They will be delighted.                 
(D)They will be discouraged.

Last names can come later.    __ Go early.__     Consider going early to conferences, parties and classes. Sometimes just a few people show up on time. That's fewer names for you to remember. And as more people arrive, you can hear them being introduced to others -- an automatic review for you.
When you meet a group of people, it is better to remember __
     A. all their names                        
(B)a couple of names first
     C. just their last names                    
(D)as many names as possible

To solve this problem, let's go through the first two paragraphs step-by-step:

1. The first paragraph discusses the idea of using large, flat, black surfaces to absorb heat from the sun and heat water. It mentions that one way to do this is to build these surfaces on the roofs of buildings.

2. However, the paragraph then questions the need to build these special surfaces, as cities are already full of black surfaces in the form of asphalt (tar) roads.

3. The second paragraph states that this idea came into the mind of Arian de Bondt, a Dutch engineer, ten years ago. It then says that he finally persuaded his boss to follow up on this idea.

Based on the information provided in the first two paragraphs, the statement that is true is:

D. Heat can also be collected from asphalt roads.

The paragraphs clearly indicate that Arian de Bondt had the idea of using the existing black surfaces of asphalt roads to collect heat, rather than building new surfaces.

The other options are not supported by the information in the first two paragraphs:

A. Arian de Bondt got his idea from his boss - the paragraphs state that Arian de Bondt came up with the idea himself.
B. Large, flat, black surfaces need to be built in cities - the paragraphs suggest that this is not necessary if the existing asphalt roads can be used instead.
C. The Dutch engineer's system has been widely used - the paragraphs do not provide any information about the widespread use of the system.
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
     Sometimes, the simplest ideas are the best. For example, to absorb heat from the sun to heat water, you need large, flat, black surfaces. One way to do that is to build those surfaces specially, on the roofs of buildings. But why go to all that trouble when cities are full of black surfaces already, in the form of asphalt (柏油) roads?     Ten years ago, this thought came into the mind of Arian de Bondt, a Dutch engineer. He finally persuaded his boss to follow it up. The result is that their building is now heated in winter and cooled in summer by a system that relies on the surface of the road outside.      The heat-collector is a system of connected water pipes. Most of them run from one side of the street to the other, just under the asphalt road. Some, however, dive deep into the ground.      When the street surface gets hot in summer, water pumped through the pipes picks up this heat and takes it underground through one of the diving pipes. At a depth of 100 metres lies a natural aquifer (蓄水层) into which several heat exchangers (交换器) have been built. The hot water from the street runs through these exchangers, warming the ground-water, before returning to the surface through another pipe. The aquifer is thus used as a heat store.      In winter, the working system is changed slightly. Water is pumped through the heat exchangers to pick up the heat stored during summer. This water goes into the building and is used to warm the place up. After performing that task, it is pumped under the asphalt and its remaining heat keeps the road free of snow and ice.
Which of the following is true according to the first two paragraphs?
      A. Arian de Bondt got his idea from his boss.
      B. Large, flat, black surfaces need to be built in cities.
(C)The Dutch engineer's system has been widely used.
(D)Heat can also be collected from asphalt roads.
question:
Sometimes, the simplest ideas are the best. For example, to absorb heat from the sun to heat water, you need large, flat, black surfaces. But why go to all that trouble when cities are full of black surfaces already, in the form of asphalt (柏油) roads?     Ten years ago, this thought came into the mind of Arian de Bondt, a Dutch engineer. He finally persuaded his boss to follow it up. The result is that their building is now heated in winter and cooled in summer by a system that relies on the surface of the road outside.      The heat-collector is a system of connected water pipes. Most of them run from one side of the street to the other, just under the asphalt road. Some, however, dive deep into the ground.      When the street surface gets hot in summer, water pumped through the pipes picks up this heat and takes it underground through one of the diving pipes. At a depth of 100 metres lies a natural aquifer (蓄水层) into which several heat exchangers (交换器) have been built. The hot water from the street runs through these exchangers, warming the ground-water, before returning to the surface through another pipe. The aquifer is thus used as a heat store.      In winter, the working system is changed slightly. Water is pumped through the heat exchangers to pick up the heat stored during summer. Which of the following is true according to the first two paragraphs?
      A. Arian de Bondt got his idea from his boss.
      B. Large, flat, black surfaces need to be built in cities.
(C)The Dutch engineer's system has been widely used.
(D)Heat can also be collected from asphalt roads.

output:
To solve this problem, we need to go through the given information step-by-step.

The passage describes a system that uses the heat from the asphalt road to heat and cool a building. The key points are:

1. The system uses a series of connected water pipes, most of which run from one side of the street to the other, just under the asphalt road.
2. Some of the pipes "dive deep into the ground" to a depth of 100 meters, where there is a natural aquifer (underground water reservoir).
3. In the summer, the hot water from the street surface is pumped through the diving pipes and into the aquifer, where it passes through heat exchangers, warming the groundwater. The hot water then returns to the surface through another pipe.
4. In the winter, the process is reversed. Water is pumped through the heat exchangers in the aquifer to pick up the stored heat, and this warm water is then used to heat the building. The remaining heat keeps the road free of snow and ice.

Based on this, the purpose of the diving pipes is to (B) store heat for future use. The pipes carry the hot water from the street surface down into the aquifer, where the heat is stored for use in the winter.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) To store heat for future use.
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
     Sometimes, the simplest ideas are the best. For example, to absorb heat from the sun to heat water, you need large, flat, black surfaces. One way to do that is to build those surfaces specially, on the roofs of buildings. But why go to all that trouble when cities are full of black surfaces already, in the form of asphalt (柏油) roads?     Ten years ago, this thought came into the mind of Arian de Bondt, a Dutch engineer. He finally persuaded his boss to follow it up. The result is that their building is now heated in winter and cooled in summer by a system that relies on the surface of the road outside.      The heat-collector is a system of connected water pipes. Most of them run from one side of the street to the other, just under the asphalt road. Some, however, dive deep into the ground.      When the street surface gets hot in summer, water pumped through the pipes picks up this heat and takes it underground through one of the diving pipes. At a depth of 100 metres lies a natural aquifer (蓄水层) into which several heat exchangers (交换器) have been built. The hot water from the street runs through these exchangers, warming the ground-water, before returning to the surface through another pipe. The aquifer is thus used as a heat store.      In winter, the working system is changed slightly. Water is pumped through the heat exchangers to pick up the heat stored during summer. This water goes into the building and is used to warm the place up. After performing that task, it is pumped under the asphalt and its remaining heat keeps the road free of snow and ice.
For what purpose are the diving pipes used?
      A. To absorb heat from the sun.
(B)To store heat for future use.
(C)To turn solar energy into heat energy.
      D. To carry heat down below the surface.

output:
To solve this problem, we need to go through the information provided in the passage step-by-step.

Step 1: Understand the overall system
The passage describes a system that uses the heat from the asphalt roads to heat and cool a building. The key components of the system are:
- Water pipes running under the asphalt road
- A deep aquifer (groundwater reservoir) with heat exchangers
- A change in the system's operation between winter and summer

Step 2: Analyze the summer operation
In summer, the hot asphalt road heats the water flowing through the pipes. This hot water is then pumped into the aquifer, where it warms the groundwater through the heat exchangers before returning to the surface.

Step 3: Analyze the winter operation
In winter, the water is pumped through the heat exchangers in the aquifer to pick up the stored heat. This warm water is then used to heat the building. After heating the building, the water is pumped back under the asphalt road, keeping the road free of snow and ice.

Step 4: Identify the correct answer
From the last paragraph, we can learn that:
A. Incorrect. The passage states that the system is "changed slightly" between winter and summer, but does not mention rearranging the pipes.
B. Correct. The passage clearly states that the system can both warm the building in winter and keep the road free of snow and ice.
C. Incorrect. The passage states that in winter, the water picks up heat from the aquifer, not the street surface.
D. Incorrect. The passage does not suggest that less heat is collected in winter than in summer. In fact, it states that the system is designed to use the heat stored in the aquifer during the summer to heat the building in the winter.

Therefore, the correct answer is B. the system can do more than warming up the building.

output:
To solve this problem, we need to go through the information provided in the passage step-by-step.

Step 1: Understand the main idea of the passage.
The passage discusses how British phone boxes, which were once a common sight in the country, are making a comeback in new and innovative ways, despite being displaced by the rise of mobile phones.

Step 2: Identify the key points about the comeback of the phone boxes.
- The phone boxes, which were once an important part of British streets, began disappearing in the 1980s due to the rise of mobile phones.
- However, some companies and individuals, like Tony Inglis, saw the value in preserving these historic structures and started repurposing them.
- The repurposed phone boxes are now being used for various purposes, such as tiny cafes, cellphone repair shops, and even housing defibrillator machines in rural areas.
- These new uses for the phone boxes are helping to preserve a piece of British history and serve important community functions.

Step 3: Determine the best answer based on the information provided.
The correct answer is (C) to remind people of a historical period.

The passage clearly states that the phone boxes are "representative of an age" and that they are making a comeback to remind people of a historical period in Britain. The passage does not mention that the phone boxes are making a comeback to form a beautiful sight of the city (A), improve telecommunications services (B), or meet the requirement of the green economy (D).
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
Sometimes it’s hard to let go. For many British people, that can apply to institutions and objects that represent their country’s past-age-old castles, splendid homes… and red phone boxes.Beaten first by the march of technology and lately by the terrible weather in junkyards (废品场), the phone boxes representative of an age are now making something of a comeback. Adapted in imaginative ways, many have reappeared on city streets and village greens housing tiny cafes, cellphone repair shops or even defibrillator machines (除颤器).The original iron boxes with the round roofs first appeared in 1926. They were designed by Giles Gilbert Scott the architect of the Battersea Power Station in London. After becoming an important part of many British streets, the phone boxes began disappearing in the 1980s, with the rise of the mobile phone sending most of them away to the junkyards.About that time, Tony Inglis’ engineering and transport company got the job to remove phone boxes from the streets and sell them out. But Inglis ended up buying hundreds of them himself, with the idea of repairing and selling them. He said that he had heard the calls to preserve the boxes and had seen how some of them were listed as historic buildings.As Inglis and, later other businessmen, got to work, repurposed phone boxes began reappearing in cities and villages as people found new uses for them. Today, they are once again a familiar sight, playing roles that are often just as important for the community as their original purpose.In rural areas, where ambulances can take a relatively long time to arrive, the phone boxes have taken on a lifesaving role. Local organizations can adopt them for l pound, and install defibrillators to help in emergencies.Others also looked at the phone boxes and saw business opportunities. LoveFone, a company that advocates repairing cellphones rather than abandoning them, opened a mini workshop in a London phone box in 2016.The tiny shops made economic sense, according to Robert Kerr, a founder of LoveFone. He said that one of the boxes generated around $13,500 in revenue a month and cost only about $400 to rent.Inglis said phone boxes called to mind an age when things were built to last. I “like what they are to people, and I enjoy bringing things back,” he said.
The phone boxes are making a comeback ______.
(A)to form a beautiful sight of the city
(B)to improve telecommunications services
(C)to remind people of a historical period
(D)to meet the requirement of green economy

question:
Sometimes it’s hard to let go. For many British people, that can apply to institutions and objects that represent their country’s past-age-old castles, splendid homes… and red phone boxes.Beaten first by the march of technology and lately by the terrible weather in junkyards (废品场), the phone boxes representative of an age are now making something of a comeback. Adapted in imaginative ways, many have reappeared on city streets and village greens housing tiny cafes, cellphone repair shops or even defibrillator machines (除颤器).The original iron boxes with the round roofs first appeared in 1926. They were designed by Giles Gilbert Scott the architect of the Battersea Power Station in London. After becoming an important part of many British streets, the phone boxes began disappearing in the 1980s, with the rise of the mobile phone sending most of them away to the junkyards.About that time, Tony Inglis’ engineering and transport company got the job to remove phone boxes from the streets and sell them out. But Inglis ended up buying hundreds of them himself, with the idea of repairing and selling them. He said that he had heard the calls to preserve the boxes and had seen how some of them were listed as historic buildings.As Inglis and, later other businessmen, got to work, repurposed phone boxes began reappearing in cities and villages as people found new uses for them. Today, they are once again a familiar sight, playing roles that are often just as important for the community as their original purpose.In rural areas, where ambulances can take a relatively long time to arrive, the phone boxes have taken on a lifesaving role. Local organizations can adopt them for l pound, and install defibrillators to help in emergencies.Others also looked at the phone boxes and saw business opportunities. LoveFone, a company that advocates repairing cellphones rather than abandoning them, opened a mini workshop in a London phone box in 2016.The tiny shops made economic sense, according to Robert Kerr, a founder of LoveFone. He said that one of the boxes generated around $13,500 in revenue a month and cost only about $400 to rent.Inglis said phone boxes called to mind an age when things were built to last. I “like what they are to people, and I enjoy bringing things back,” he said.
The phone boxes are becoming popular mainly because of ______.
(A)their new appearance and lower prices
(B)the push of the local organizations
(C)their changed roles and functions
(D)the big funding of the businessmen

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the text step-by-step:

1. The first paragraph mentions that "For those who can stomach it, working out before breakfast may be more beneficial for health than eating first".

2. The underlined expression "stomach it" is used in this context.

3. Based on the context, "stomach it" most likely means being able to manage or tolerate working out without having breakfast first.

4. Looking at the answer choices:
(A) "digest the meal easily" does not fit the context.
(B) "manage without breakfast" is the closest meaning to the usage in the text.
(C) "decide wisely what to eat" is not the meaning conveyed here.
(D) "eat whatever is offered" is not relevant to the context.

Therefore, the answer that best fits the meaning of the underlined expression "stomach it" is:
(B) manage without breakfast
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
For those who can stomach it, working out before breakfast may be more beneficial for health than eating first, according to a study of meal timing and physical activity.Athletes and scientists have long known that meal timing affects performance. However, far less has been known about how meal timing and exercise might affect general health.To find out, British scientists conducted a study. They first found 10 overweight and inactive but otherwise healthy young men, whose lifestyles are, for better and worse, representative of those of most of us. They tested the men’s fitness and resting metabolic (新陈代谢的) rates and took samples (样品) of their blood and fat tissue.Then, on two separate morning visits to the scientists’ lab, each man walked for an hour at an average speed that, in theory should allow his body to rely mainly on fat for fuel. Before one of these workouts, the men skipped breakfast, meaning that they exercised on a completely empty stomach after a long overnight fast (禁食). On the other occasion, they ate a rich morning meal about two hours before they started walking.Just before and an hour after each workout, the scientists took additional samples of the men’s blood and fat tissue.Then they compared the samples. There were considerable differences. Most obviously, the men displayed lower blood sugar levels at the start of their workouts when they had skipped breakfast than when they had eaten. As a result, they burned more fat during walks on an empty stomach than when they had eaten first. On the other hand, they burned slightly more calories (卡路里), on average, during the workout after breakfast than after fasting.But it was the effects deep within the fat cells that may have been the most significant, the researchers found. Multiple genes behaved differently, depending on whether someone had eaten or not before walking. Many of these genes produce proteins (蛋白质) that can improve blood sugar regulation and insulin (胰岛素) levels throughout the body and so are associated with improved metabolic health. These genes were much more active when the men had fasted before exercise than when they had breakfasted.The implication of these results is that to gain the greatest health benefits from exercise, it may be wise to skip eating first.
The underlined expression “stomach it” in Paragraph 1 most probably means “______”.
(A)digest the meal easily
(B)manage without breakfast
(C)decide wisely what to eat
(D)eat whatever is offered

To solve this problem, let's break down the key information from the passage and then answer the question.

Key information:
1. The study involved 10 overweight and inactive but otherwise healthy young men.
2. The men went through two separate morning exercise sessions:
   a. One session where they skipped breakfast and exercised on an empty stomach.
   b. One session where they had a rich morning meal about 2 hours before exercising.
3. The researchers took blood and fat tissue samples before and after each exercise session.
4. The key findings were:
   a. The men displayed lower blood sugar levels at the start of the exercise when they had skipped breakfast.
   b. They burned more fat during the walks on an empty stomach compared to when they had eaten first.
   c. They burned slightly more calories on average during the workout after breakfast than after fasting.
   d. Multiple genes related to blood sugar regulation and insulin levels were more active when the men had fasted before exercise.

Now, let's answer the question:

What happened to those who ate breakfast before exercise?

The correct answer is (D) They displayed higher insulin levels.

The passage states that "Many of these genes produce proteins that can improve blood sugar regulation and insulin levels throughout the body and so are associated with improved metabolic health. These genes were much more active when the men had fasted before exercise than when they had breakfasted."

This indicates that the men who ate breakfast before exercise displayed higher insulin levels, which is the opposite of the more beneficial metabolic effects seen in those who fasted before exercise.

The study aimed to investigate how meal timing and exercise might affect general health, specifically focusing on the impact of exercising before or after breakfast.

The researchers recruited 10 overweight and inactive but otherwise healthy young men. They tested the men's fitness, resting metabolic rates, and collected blood and fat tissue samples. Based on the study results, the researchers concluded that to gain the greatest health benefits from exercise, it may be better to skip eating first and exercise on an empty stomach.

Therefore, the correct answer is (D) Physical exercise before breakfast is better for health.

To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step:

1. The passage describes the author and his wife arriving in a remote village in the Amazon rainforest. The key details are:
- They flew to the village on a small plane
- They did not speak the local language or know the customs
- They often did not recognize the food
- They felt very foreign and out of place in this new environment

2. The passage states that "It was easy for us to go to sleep at the end of the day feeling a little misunderstood." This suggests that the author and his wife felt out of place and misunderstood in the village.

3. The passage does not mention the author or his wife feeling full of joy, sleepy, or regretful upon arriving in the Amazon. 

Therefore, the answer that best describes how the author felt on his arrival in the Amazon is (A) Out of place.
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
I was in the middle of the Amazon (亚马逊) with my wife, who was there as a medical researcher. We flew on a small plane to a faraway village. We did not speak the local language, did not know the customs, and more often than not, did not entirely recognize the food. We could not have felt more foreign.We were raised on books and computers, highways and cell phones, but now we were living in a village without running water or electricity It was easy for us to go to sleep at the end of the day feeling a little misunderstood.Then one perfect Amazonian evening, with monkeys calling from beyond the village green, we played soccer. I am not good at soccer, but that evening it was wonderful. Everyone knew the rules. We all spoke the same language of passes and shots. We understood one another perfectly. As darkness came over the field and the match ended, the goal keeper, Juan, walked over to me and said in a matter-of-fact way, “In your home, do you have a moon too?” I was surprised.After I explained to Juan that yes, we did have a moon and yes, it was very similar to his, I felt a sort of awe (敬畏) at the possibilities that existed in his world. In Juan’s world, each village could have its own moon. In Juan’s world. the unknown and undiscovered was vast and marvelous. Anything was possible.In our society, we know that Earth has only one moon. We have looked at our planet from every angle and found all of the wildest things left to find. I can, from my computer at home, pull up satellite images of Juan’s village. There are no more continents and no more moons to search for, little left to discover. At least it seems that way.Yet, as I thought about Juan’s question, I was not sure how much more we could really rule out. I am, in part, an ant biologist, so my thoughts turned to what we know about insect life and I knew that much in the world of insects remains unknown. How much, though? How ignorant  (无知的) are we? The question of what we know and do not know constantly bothered me.I began collecting newspaper articles about new species, new monkey, new spider…, and on and on they appear. My drawer quickly filled. I began a second drawer for more general discoveries: new cave system discovered with dozens of nameless species, four hundred species of bacteria found in the human stomach. The second drawer began to fill and as it did I wondered whether there were bigger discoveries out there, not just species, but life that depends on things thought to be useless, life even without DNA. I started a third drawer for these big discoveries. It fills more slowly, but all the same, it fills.In looking into the stories of biological discovery, I also began to find something else, a collection of scientists, usually brilliant occasionally half-mad, who made the discoveries. Those scientists very often see the same things that other scientists see, but they pay more attention to them, and they focus on them to the point of exhaustion (穷尽), and at the risk of the ridicule of their peers. In looking for the stories of discovery, I found the stories of these people and how their lives changed our view of the world.We are repeatedly willing to imagine we have found most of what is left to discover. We used to think that insects were the smallest organisms (生物), and that nothing lived deeper than six hundred meters. Yet, when something new turns up, more often than not, we do not even know its name.
How did the author feel on his arrival in the Amazon?
(A)Out of place.
(B)Full of joy.
(C)Sleepy.
(D)Regretful.

prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
I was in the middle of the Amazon (亚马逊) with my wife, who was there as a medical researcher. We flew on a small plane to a faraway village. We did not speak the local language, did not know the customs, and more often than not, did not entirely recognize the food. We could not have felt more foreign.We were raised on books and computers, highways and cell phones, but now we were living in a village without running water or electricity It was easy for us to go to sleep at the end of the day feeling a little misunderstood.Then one perfect Amazonian evening, with monkeys calling from beyond the village green, we played soccer. I am not good at soccer, but that evening it was wonderful. Everyone knew the rules. We all spoke the same language of passes and shots. We understood one another perfectly. As darkness came over the field and the match ended, the goal keeper, Juan, walked over to me and said in a matter-of-fact way, “In your home, do you have a moon too?” I was surprised.After I explained to Juan that yes, we did have a moon and yes, it was very similar to his, I felt a sort of awe (敬畏) at the possibilities that existed in his world. In Juan’s world, each village could have its own moon. In Juan’s world. the unknown and undiscovered was vast and marvelous. Anything was possible.In our society, we know that Earth has only one moon. We have looked at our planet from every angle and found all of the wildest things left to find. I can, from my computer at home, pull up satellite images of Juan’s village. There are no more continents and no more moons to search for, little left to discover. At least it seems that way.Yet, as I thought about Juan’s question, I was not sure how much more we could really rule out. I am, in part, an ant biologist, so my thoughts turned to what we know about insect life and I knew that much in the world of insects remains unknown. How much, though? How ignorant  (无知的) are we? The question of what we know and do not know constantly bothered me.I began collecting newspaper articles about new species, new monkey, new spider…, and on and on they appear. My drawer quickly filled. I began a second drawer for more general discoveries: new cave system discovered with dozens of nameless species, four hundred species of bacteria found in the human stomach. The second drawer began to fill and as it did I wondered whether there were bigger discoveries out there, not just species, but life that depends on things thought to be useless, life even without DNA. I started a third drawer for these big discoveries. It fills more slowly, but all the same, it fills.In looking into the stories of biological discovery, I also began to find something else, a collection of scientists, usually brilliant occasionally half-mad, who made the discoveries. Those scientists very often see the same things that other scientists see, but they pay more attention to them, and they focus on them to the point of exhaustion (穷尽), and at the risk of the ridicule of their peers. In looking for the stories of discovery, I found the stories of these people and how their lives changed our view of the world.We are repeatedly willing to imagine we have found most of what is left to discover. We used to think that insects were the smallest organisms (生物), and that nothing lived deeper than six hundred meters. Yet, when something new turns up, more often than not, we do not even know its name.
What made that Amazonian evening wonderful?
(A)He learned more about the local language.
(B)They had a nice conversation with each other.
(C)They understood each other while playing.
(D)He won the soccer game with the goal keeper.

It fills more slowly, but all the same, it fills.In looking into the stories of biological discovery, I also began to find something else, a collection of scientists, usually brilliant occasionally half-mad, who made the discoveries. Those scientists very often see the same things that other scientists see, but they pay more attention to them, and they focus on them to the point of exhaustion (穷尽), and at the risk of the ridicule of their peers. In looking for the stories of discovery, I found the stories of these people and how their lives changed our view of the world.We are repeatedly willing to imagine we have found most of what is left to discover. We used to think that insects were the smallest organisms (生物), and that nothing lived deeper than six hundred meters. Yet, when something new turns up, more often than not, we do not even know its name.
How did those brilliant scientists make great discoveries?
(A)They shifted their viewpoints frequently.
(B)They followed other scientists closely.
(C)They often criticized their fellow scientists.
(D)They conducted in-depth and close studies.

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step and analyze the main ideas and themes to determine the most suitable title.

1. The passage describes the experience of the narrator and his wife, who were in the Amazon as medical researchers. They felt very foreign and disconnected from the local village, unable to communicate or recognize the customs and food.

2. However, one evening while playing soccer with the villagers, the narrator felt a sense of understanding and connection, despite the language barrier. This was highlighted by the village goalkeeper's question about the moon.

3. The passage then delves into a broader discussion about the contrast between what we know and what remains unknown in the world. The narrator reflects on how in modern society, we feel that most of the major discoveries have been made, with little left to explore.

4. However, the narrator starts collecting evidence that there is still much more to discover, both in terms of new species and even more fundamental aspects of life and the natural world.

5. The passage also touches on the role of scientists who are willing to challenge the conventional wisdom and make groundbreaking discoveries, often facing ridicule from their peers.

Based on this analysis, the most suitable title for the passage is:

(B) The Known and the Unknown

This title captures the central theme of the passage, which is the tension between what we think we know and understand about the world, and the vast realms of the unknown that still remain to be explored and discovered. The passage contrasts the narrator's initial feelings of being in a foreign, unknown world, with the later realization that there is still so much more to uncover.
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
I was in the middle of the Amazon (亚马逊) with my wife, who was there as a medical researcher. We flew on a small plane to a faraway village. We did not speak the local language, did not know the customs, and more often than not, did not entirely recognize the food. We could not have felt more foreign.We were raised on books and computers, highways and cell phones, but now we were living in a village without running water or electricity It was easy for us to go to sleep at the end of the day feeling a little misunderstood.Then one perfect Amazonian evening, with monkeys calling from beyond the village green, we played soccer. I am not good at soccer, but that evening it was wonderful. Everyone knew the rules. We all spoke the same language of passes and shots. We understood one another perfectly. As darkness came over the field and the match ended, the goal keeper, Juan, walked over to me and said in a matter-of-fact way, “In your home, do you have a moon too?” I was surprised.After I explained to Juan that yes, we did have a moon and yes, it was very similar to his, I felt a sort of awe (敬畏) at the possibilities that existed in his world. In Juan’s world, each village could have its own moon. In Juan’s world. the unknown and undiscovered was vast and marvelous. Anything was possible.In our society, we know that Earth has only one moon. We have looked at our planet from every angle and found all of the wildest things left to find. I can, from my computer at home, pull up satellite images of Juan’s village. There are no more continents and no more moons to search for, little left to discover. At least it seems that way.Yet, as I thought about Juan’s question, I was not sure how much more we could really rule out. I am, in part, an ant biologist, so my thoughts turned to what we know about insect life and I knew that much in the world of insects remains unknown. How much, though? How ignorant  (无知的) are we? The question of what we know and do not know constantly bothered me.I began collecting newspaper articles about new species, new monkey, new spider…, and on and on they appear. My drawer quickly filled. I began a second drawer for more general discoveries: new cave system discovered with dozens of nameless species, four hundred species of bacteria found in the human stomach. The second drawer began to fill and as it did I wondered whether there were bigger discoveries out there, not just species, but life that depends on things thought to be useless, life even without DNA. I started a third drawer for these big discoveries. It fills more slowly, but all the same, it fills.In looking into the stories of biological discovery, I also began to find something else, a collection of scientists, usually brilliant occasionally half-mad, who made the discoveries. Those scientists very often see the same things that other scientists see, but they pay more attention to them, and they focus on them to the point of exhaustion (穷尽), and at the risk of the ridicule of their peers. In looking for the stories of discovery, I found the stories of these people and how their lives changed our view of the world.We are repeatedly willing to imagine we have found most of what is left to discover. We used to think that insects were the smallest organisms (生物), and that nothing lived deeper than six hundred meters. Yet, when something new turns up, more often than not, we do not even know its name.
What could be the most suitable title for the passage?
(A)The Possible and the Impossible .
(B)The Known and the Unknown .
(C)The Civilized and the Uncivilized .
(D)The Ignorant and the Intelligent.

To solve this problem, we need to identify the key information provided in the passage and then determine the answer based on the given options.

The passage discusses the benefits and requirements for students to take e-learning courses through the Toronto District School Board (TDSB). It mentions that students who are successful in online courses are usually:

1. Able to plan, organize time, and complete assignments and activities.
2. Capable of working independently in a responsible and honest manner.
3. Able to regularly use a computer or mobile device with internet access.

(B) To do their assignments independently.

This suggests that one of the key requirements for completing e-learning courses is the ability to work independently on assignments and activities.

(A) To learn information technology online is not mentioned as a requirement.
(C) Updating mobile devices regularly is not specifically mentioned as a requirement.
(D) Talking face-to-face with teachers is not listed as a requirement for e-learning courses, as the passage states that the courses are provided in an "on-line classroom."

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) To do their assignments independently.

Ann，who at that time only ranked number 70 in the world，beat Jamaica's unchallenged queen of the sprint（短跑）．"Where did she come from？"asked an astonished sprinting world，before concluding that she must be one of those one﹣hit wonders that spring up from time to time，only to disappear again without signs．But Shelly Ann was to prove that she was anything but a one﹣hit wonder．At the Beijing Not so long ago，most people didn't know who Shelly Ann Francis Pryce was going to become．She was just an average high school athlete．There was every indication that she was just another American teenager without much of a future．However，one person wants to change this．Stephen Francis observed then eighteen﹣year﹣old Shelly Ann as a track meet and was convinced that he had seen the beginning of true greatness．Her time were not exactly impressive，but even so，he seemed there was something trying to get out，something the other coaches had overlooked when they had assessed her and found her lacking．He decided to offer Shelly Ann a place in his very strict training seasons．Their cooperation quickly produced results，and a few year later at Jamaica's Olympic games in early 2008，Shelly Ann，who at that time only ranked number 70 in the world，beat Jamaica's unchallenged queen of the sprint（短跑）．"Where did she come from？"asked an astonished sprinting world，before concluding that she must be one of those one﹣hit wonders that spring up from time to time，only to disappear again without signs．But Shelly Ann was to prove that she was anything but a one﹣hit wonder．At the Beijing Olympic she swept away any doubts about her ability to perform consistently by becoming the first Jamaican woman ever to win the 100 meters Olympic gold．She did it again one year on at the World Championship in Briton，becoming world champion with a time of 10.73﹣﹣﹣the fourth record ever．Shelly﹣Ann is a little woman with a big smile．She has a mental toughness that did not come about by chance．Her journey to becoming the fastest woman on earth has been anything but smooth and effortless．She grew up in one of Jamaica's toughest inner﹣city communities known as Waterhouse，where she lived in a one﹣room apartment，sleeping four in a bed with her mother and two brothers．Waterhouse，one  of the poorest communities in Jamaica，is a really violent and overpopulated place．Several of Shelly﹣Ann's friends and family were caught up in the killings； one of her cousins was shot dead only a few streets away from where she lived．Sometimes her family didn't have enough to eat．She ran at the school championships barefooted because she couldn't afford shoes．Her mother Maxime，one of a family of fourteen，had been an athlete herself as a young girl but，like so many other girls in Waterhouse，had to stop after she had her first baby．Maxime's early entry in to the adult world with its responsibilities gave her the determination to ensure that her kids would not end up in Waterhouse's roundabout of poverty．One of the first things Maxime used to do with Shelly﹣Ann was taking her to the track，and she was ready to sacrifice everything．It didn't take long for Shelly﹣Ann to realize that sports could be her way out of Waterhouse．On a summer evening in Beijing in 2008，all those long，hard hours of work and commitment finally bore fruit．The barefoot kid who just a few years previously had been living in poverty，surrounded by criminals and violence，had written a new chapter in the history of sports．But Shelly﹣Ann's victory was far greater than that．The night she won Olympic gold in Beijing，the routine murders in Waterhouse and the drug wars in the neighbouring streets stopped．The dark cloud above one of the world's toughest criminal neighbourhoods simply disappeared for a few days．"I have so much fire burning for my country，"Shelly said．She plans to start a foundation for homeless children and wants to build a community centre in Waterhouse．She hopes to inspire the Jamaicans to lay down their weapons．She intends to fight to make it a woman's as well as a man's world．As Muhammad Al i puts it，"Champions aren't made in gyms．Champions are made from something they have deep inside them．A desire，a dream，a vision．"One of the things Shelly﹣Ann can be proud of is her understanding of this truth．
68．What can we infer from Shelly﹣Ann's statement underlined in Paragraph 5？
(A)She was highly rewarded for her efforts．
(B)She was eager to do more for her country．
(C)She became an athletic star in her country．
(D)She was the envy of the whole community．

To solve this problem, I will go through the following steps:

1. Understand the context and the question:
The passage is about the story of Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, a Jamaican sprinter who became the fastest woman on earth. The question is asking about the author's intention in using the quote from Muhammad Ali.

2. Analyze the quote and the context:
The quote from Muhammad Ali states that "Champions are made from something they have deep inside them. A desire, a dream, a vision." This suggests that great athletes are not made just in the gym, but through their inner motivation and determination.

3. Evaluate the options:
(A) Players should be highly inspired by coaches - This is not the main point of the quote. The quote is about the athlete's inner drive, not the coach's role.
(B) Great athletes need to concentrate on patience - The quote does not mention anything about patience. It focuses on the athlete's inner desire, dream, and vision.
(C) Hard work is necessary in one's achievements - This is correct. The quote suggests that champions are made from their inner drive and determination, which fuels their hard work and achievements.
(D) Motivation allows great athletes to be on the top - This is also correct, as the quote emphasizes the importance of inner motivation and vision in becoming a champion.

4. Choose the best answer:
Based on the analysis, the correct answer is (C) and (D), as both options accurately reflect the message of the Muhammad Ali quote in the context of the passage.

output:
To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step and identify the key information that would help determine the best title.

Step 1: Understand the main focus of the passage.
The passage is about the life story of Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, a Jamaican sprinter who became the fastest woman on earth. It describes her humble beginnings, the hardships she faced, and her journey to becoming an Olympic champion.

Step 2: Identify the key events and turning points in the passage.
- Shelly-Ann was just an average high school athlete, but her coach Stephen Francis saw her potential.
- Francis offered her a place in his strict training program, which quickly produced results.
- Shelly-Ann went on to win the 100m gold medal at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, becoming the first Jamaican woman to do so.
- She continued to dominate the sprinting events, winning multiple world championships.
- Shelly-Ann's journey was marked by overcoming poverty, violence, and lack of resources in her hometown of Waterhouse, Jamaica.
- Her Olympic success had a profound impact on her community, even stopping the routine violence for a few days.

Step 3: Evaluate the potential titles.
(A) "The Making of a Great Athlete" - This title captures the essence of the passage, as it focuses on Shelly-Ann's transformation from an average high school athlete to a world-class sprinter.
(B) "The Dream for Championship" - This title is too broad and does not specifically address Shelly-Ann's story.
(C) "The Key to High Performance" - This title is also too broad and does not fully reflect the personal and socioeconomic aspects of Shelly-Ann's journey.
(D) "The Power of Full Responsibility" - This title does not accurately represent the main focus of the passage, which is the story of Shelly-Ann's rise to success.

Based on the analysis, the best title for the passage is (A) "The Making of a Great Athlete".

To solve this problem, I will go through the passage step-by-step:

1. The passage discusses the experience of rereading a book that one has read many times before. It says that rereading can feel like "drinks with an old friend" - there is a "welcome familiarity" but also a sense that the reader has changed over time, and thus the relationship with the book has changed.

2. The key point made is that "books don't change, people do. And that's what makes the act of rereading so rich and transformative." The author is suggesting that rereading allows the reader to see the book through their own changing perspectives and experiences.

3. The author then discusses three books they reread annually, and mentions that they were given these books as gifts, which adds to the meaning they attach to them.

4. The author concludes by saying that rereading an author's work is "the highest currency a reader can pay them" because the best books "open further as time passes" - it's the reader who has to "grow and read and reread in order to better understand" the book.

Based on this, the correct answer is (D) - rereading extends the understanding of oneself. The passage emphasizes that rereading allows the reader to see the book through their own changing perspectives and experiences over time, which helps them better understand themselves.
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
Returning to a book you’ve read many times can feel like drinks with an old friend. There’s a welcome familiarity - but also sometimes a slight suspicion that time has changed you both, and thus the relationship. But books don’t change, people do. And that’s what makes the act of rereading so rich and transformative.The beauty of rereading lies in the idea that our bond with the work is based on our present mental register. It’s true, the older I get, the more I feel time has wings. But with reading, it’s all about the present. It’s about the now and what one contributes to the now, because reading is a give and take between author and reader. Each has to pull their own weight.There are three books I reread annually The first, which I take to reading every spring is Emest Hemningway’s A Moveable Feast. Published in 1964, it’s his classic memoir of 1920s Paris. The language is almost intoxicating (令人陶醉的)，an aging writer looking back on an ambitious yet simpler time. Another is Annie Dillard’s Holy the Firm, her poetic 1975 ramble (随笔) about everything and nothing. The third book is Julio Cortazar’s Save Twilight: Selected Poems, because poetry. And because Cortazar.While I tend to buy a lot of books, these three were given to me as gifs, which might add to the meaning I attach to them. But I imagine that, while money is indeed wonderful and necessary, rereading an author’s work is the highest currency a reader can pay them. The best books are the ones that open further as time passes. But remember, it’s you that has to grow and read and reread in order to better understand your friends.
Why does the author like rereading?
(A)It evaluates the writer-reader relationship.
(B)It’s a window to a whole new world.
(C)It’s a substitute for drinking with a friend.
(D)It extends the understanding of oneself.

To solve this problem, we need to understand the key information provided in the passage.

The passage states that the longest track and field event at the Summer Olympics is the 50-kilometer race walk, which is about five miles longer than the marathon. It also mentions that the sport's rules require that a race walker's knees stay straight through most of the leg swing and one foot remain in contact with the ground at all times.

Based on this information, the correct answer is:

(C) They have to follow special rules.

The passage explains that the unique rules of race walking, such as the requirement to keep one foot in contact with the ground at all times and maintain a straight leg swing, make race walkers "conditioned athletes." These special rules require race walkers to be highly trained and conditioned to perform the specific techniques of race walking.

The other options are not supported by the passage:
(A) They do not have to run long distances, but rather walk long distances.
(B) The passage does not mention race walkers being qualified for the marathon.
(D) While leg swing is important, the passage does not suggest that race walkers are particularly good at this aspect compared to other athletes.

Therefore, the correct answer is (C) They have to follow special rules.
prompt:
Solve the following task. Solve the problem by thinking step-by-step.
Race walking shares many fitness benefits with running, research shows, while most likely contributing to fewer injuries. It does, however, have its own problem.Race walkers are conditioned athletes. The longest track and field event at the Summer Olympics is the 50-kilometer race walk, which is about five miles longer than the marathon. But the sport’s rules require that a race walker’s knees stay straight through most of the leg swing and one foot remain in contact (接触) with the ground at all times. It’s this strange form that makes race walking such an attractive activity, however, says Jaclyn Norberg, an assistant professor of exercise science at Salem State University in Salem, Mass.Like running, race walking is physically demanding, she says, According to most calculations, race walkers moving at a pace of six miles per hour would burn about 800 calories(卡路里) per hour, which is approximately twice as many as they would burn walking, although fewer than running, which would probably burn about 1,000 or more calories per hour.However, race walking does not pound the body as much as running does, Dr. Norberg says. According to her research, runners hit the ground with as much as four times their body weight per step, while race walkers, who do not leave the ground, create only about 1.4 times their body weight with each step.As a result, she says, some of the injuries associated with running, such as runner’s knee, are uncommon among race walkers. But the sport’s strange form does place considerable stress on the ankles and hips, so people with a history of such injuries might want to be cautious in adopting the sport. In fact, anyone wishing to try race walking should probably first consult a coach or experienced racer to learn proper technique, she says. It takes some practice.
Why are race walkers conditioned athletes?
(A)They must run long distances.
(B)They are qualified for the marathon.
(C)They have to follow special rules.
(D)They are good at swinging their legs.

But the sport’s strange form does place considerable stress on the ankles and hips, so people with a history of such injuries might want to be cautious in adopting the sport. In fact, anyone wishing to try race walking should probably first consult a coach or experienced racer to learn proper technique, she says. It takes some practice.
What is Dr. Norberg’s suggestion for someone trying race walking?
(A)Getting experts’ opinions.
(B)Having a medical checkup.
(C)Hiring an experienced coach.
(D)Doing regular exercises.

But the sport’s strange form does place considerable stress on the ankles and hips, so people with a history of such injuries might want to be cautious in adopting the sport. In fact, anyone wishing to try race walking should probably first consult a coach or experienced racer to learn proper technique, she says. It takes some practice.
